question: Under which condition is flow through a river boundary considered 'constant' (i.e., flow is not dependent on aquifer head)? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. Constant flow occurs if the aquifer head is below the riverbed bottom.
error: ❌ Review the RIV section to better understand when MODFLOW sets flow to a constant value — it depends on the aquifer head.

question: What happens when the aquifer head is higher than the river stage and both are above the riverbed bottom? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. This is a typical 'gaining river' case, where the aquifer discharges to the river.
error: ❌ Flow direction depends on the relative heads — reconsider which is higher, the aquifer head or river stage and the resulting direction of water movement.

question: Which of the following factors influence the maximum flow from river to aquifer in MODFLOW’s RIV package? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. All four parameters affect the flow. Conductance scales the head difference, and the riverbed bottom elevation determines the upper bound to the amount of water that can flow into the aquifer.
error: ❌ All listed parameters are involved in determining flow magnitude and direction.

question: In a scenario where the riverbed conductance is low, what is the expected behavior? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. A low conductance limits the flow, and results in a low slope of the  Q–h plot.
error: ❌ Review the RIV section to better understand the role of conductance and the influence of conductance on the slope of the Q–h plot. Conductance reflects the ease with which water flows across the interface and there is little flow even for large head differences.

question: Why does MODFLOW limit river recharge when aquifer head is below the riverbed bottom? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. MODFLOW restricts river recharge below the bottom to reflect unsaturated conditions below the river. Without restriction the river seepage would be unrealistic.
error: ❌ The restriction is due to unsaturated conditions beneath the riverbed, it is not related to conductance and the river cells remain active. Without this restriction an unrealistic amount of water would flow out of the river.

question: When the aquifer head equals the river stage, and both are above the bottom, what is the flow? (Mark ALL correct answers)
success: ✅ Correct. No flow occurs when heads are equal — the system is balanced.
error: ❌ If there is no difference in head, then there is no driving force and there will be no flow no matter the values of other parameters.
